review_title: great group of people and great experiences
pros: Good employee experience especially for the young people. Great benefits, lots of time off, holidays its closed get to spend time with family and friends. Lots of learning development and lots of new tools and skills to learn. You gain access to high profile leaders externally and internally, all while making a great difference through programs and initiatives to support young people locally and internationally.
cons: The normal growing pains that the leadership is always working to improve

pros: - I learned a lot about how to deal with difficult people
cons: - degrading towards employees, working hard for little pay, expected to work long hours - base salary for womxn is significantly less than the males (a couple of male coworkers disclosed their salary and it was roughly 45% more than my own) which was brought up to the director who justified it with "You're just a junior" --- a "junior" who was the ONLY one with experience working with their ridiculous code bases, put up with their BS after the whole team left (due to shotty management and lack of transparency), and even after leaving the org, they'd still contact a "junior" for help - promises of new work gave hope whilst being entirely disregarded when it came to career goals - felt like a cult, shady operations, poor choices for hiring executives/upper management – if you didn't drink the kool-aid or say "YES SIR" to anything extra they'd ask of you beyond your job's scope

job_title: Youth & Family Engagement Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Colleagues were often supportive and collaborative Good location Could rationalize that you were doing some good for the world Some opportunity to gain experience/pivot to different fields
cons: -Exploitative workplace - low salaries, long hours, limited or no lieu days -People managers often unequipped to do an effective job -Executive team tried to treat org as a fortune 500 company and seemed disconnected from their staff and the overall mission

pros: Great colleagues, lovely office space
cons: Unfair wages and annual raise not provided, despite working overtime often

pros: Good experience for entry level individuals Young and fun culture
cons: People were only respected by senior leadership if they were highly loyal. Otherwise there was high turnover among lower level individuals.

review_title: Overall, still in therapy from the trauma endured working at WE
pros:
- Work Besties
- Travel Opportunities
- Supporting local & global philanthropic projects
cons:
- Burnout culture
- Salary pay that worked out to be $8.50/hr
- Felt pushed away from friends and family with mandatory workshops or event commitments on many major holidays.
- No pay for working on stat. holidays, yes this is illegal. 
- Power structure causing hierarchical communication barriers 
- Hookup culture, everyone was sleeping with each other (especially in upper management) this made it very difficult to navigate work culture, communication, and was very uncomfortable for staff at the least.

Overall the experience working here felt very cliquey and ruined what could have been such a great work culture. Many people work here to be with like minded people but it was toxic and promoted nepotism.

pros: I appreciated the work they did for the schools across Canada, USA, and UK and the work they did in the countries they were in.
cons:
Everything you saw on CBC or in the news during the pandemic are all true.
Shady management.
Shady leadership team.

review_title: Didnt have to be so bad
pros: Great people to work collaborate with
cons:
Used old theories on international development - little to no room to critique. 
Poor upper leadership

pros:
Cool people usually
Easy work if you don't get into it too much
Slightly less scummy feeling than working for a megacorp

cons:
Will never give you a raise, ever
Will lie about why you won't get a raise
Will not help you develop your skills professionally

pros: Vibrant young group of people to work with. Most people's first job -- everyone's learning. Get to travel. Lots of perks.
cons: LONG hours and you are expected to work them no matter what.

pros: Nice office, friendly coworkers, good networking opps
cons: Poor leadership from senior team

pros: Travel opportunities, and fast paced environment
cons: Tough to advance and move up.

pros: Amazing culture of being aware of important issues. Genuinely good people work there.
cons: When an employee leaves they have a habit of having staff just pick up the work. Leads to one employee doing many peoples jobs for the same salary.

pros: Likeminded colleagues - hard to think of anything else.
cons: Little work life balance, poor pay for the amount of work, not working with like minded organizations, leadership is exploitative

review_title: FTC is by far the best possible career choice for young professionals and new grads
pros: After 2 years of working for FTC, I can easily say that my experience went above and beyond what I ever imagined as my first job out of university.  I was given every opportunity to learn and grow on a daily basis, and was rewarded for my work through promotions within my team.  With the continued growth trajectory of this business, you will learn to work at a fast pace and have the chance to work on projects that will both challenge and inspire you.  Senior management will push you to take the lead on major projects and provide mentorship that will be invaluable to you as a young professional.  I had the opportunity to work with the Executive Director, Scott Baker, on a daily basis and was given every opportunity to provide input and manage projects with his guidance and leadership.  As a result of the extensive opportunities afforded to me, I learned more in two years working here than I anticipated I would in ten.  I will continue to recommend this organization to new grads and young professionals for many years to come!
cons: I have read reviews that critique the long hours required at this organization and I would humbly say that if you are looking for a 9 to 5 job, this place is not the right fit for you.  That said, if you are interested in learning outside of your comfort zone, moving at a fast pace in a tech startup-style environment, and challenging yourself everyday, then you will absolutely feel fulfilled and satisfied with your career choice -- and it will pay off in the long run.

review_title: This is not just a job, it is a career, FULL of opportunity
pros:
- You end up making best friends here
- you are given opportunities every day to expand your skills 
- one thing you can count on is that the organization is always changing; you will never  get bored and you will always be exposed to new and exciting challenges
- You will work HARD here
- more experience and responsibilities given to staff than would be given in other companies to millennials 
- two wks holidays PLUS Christmas shut down 
- Staff trip to Kenya/Ecuador

It appears that people only write on this site when they have had a bad experience. The fact is, you are responsible for determining what kind of experience you have and what you share. FTC is explicit when you start that it is NOT a 9-5 job, that the salary is X amount in year 1, X amount in year 2. Nobody is hiding this information from staff so if you leave feeling bitter about either of these things, it is your own fault because you came into the org with full disclosure. And if you followed a corporate career path, you would likely still be paid a salary and still expected to work more than 44 hours a week - the difference is what motivates you: money or your social responsibility.
cons:
- Giving Coordinators and Managers more face time with founders, not just in times of stress. 
- investing in your staff is always a good thing (not just social parties). I have no problem with the salary but so many people do bring this issue up. Coordinators have not had a raise in their starting salary in 3 years - now is the time.

pros: Loved working there because of the people
cons: Definitely a lack of work-life balance

review_title: They’re Shuttering Their Doors for a Reason
pros: The people working there at the Assistant Director level and lower were generally genuinely looking to make the world a better place.
cons: The entire thing boiled down to a vanity project for the brothers. They grew the organization too fast because it looked good on paper and allowed for glamorous arena events with celebrities, but they were losing money long before the pandemic and government scandal.

pros:
Great people and sense of team. 
Interesting connections with government funders, corporate partners. Great opportunity to broaden perspective of nonprofit work in Canada.
cons:
Limited growth opportunities for experienced professionals;
Concerning optimism for some projects without considering critical histories and lived experiences of recipients.

review_title: Sad to see the team gone
pros: Great learning opportunities for young people
cons: Shut down due to a political scandal.

review_title: They're getting what they deserve now in the media for their crookedness and greed of money
job_title: Marketing And Communications Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Great experience as you are overworked and learn a lot.
cons: Salary was never the topic of discussion and you were shut down whenever you asked for more money.

pros:
I have been working here for over 4 years and despite the many issues, I do go home every night knowing that my work and effort during the day or week is going to something way bigger than myself, colleagues or bosses.  Being able ensure that a kid somewhere far away from my warm and privileged town is able to access a good education, together with a meal, and likely further enhanced training to make something of their lives- has come to define ME.  And for someone to see only the issues that affect their small world...my Director was mean to me, or I didn't get my treat today.... makes me mad and sad at the same time.  

At FTC, I have seen my efforts transform communities in the places we work in and no matter how much anyone say's, I will continue to put in my heart and spirit into it.
cons: I think that for us in the mother ship, not to loose sight of what we do, hq management should invite speakers from the communities we support, to give us their own versions of how they see the work of FTC affecting them and their communities- I feel this is not done regularly enough, leading to staff loosing sight of where they are going.

review_title: Hard work and right mindset needed to thrive
pros: The people here are the best I have ever met. Our team is really well supported by a strong director who knows how to motivate and inspire, we often hit our goals and exceed what is asked of us. We are a part of a close knit group of professionals and I know my Director does everything she possibly can to listen to us and support our growth. She is there for us, checks in regularly and champions and celebrates our work.  Over the past two years, I have been able to travel on trips, I have hosted influential stakeholders in Kenya and India and have been able to grow in the organization which has made working here a valuable professional experience. I grew up in an entrepreneurial family watching my parents work around the clock to develop their business so working hard and at unpredictable hours is second nature to me. I see value in this type of work experience for my future.
cons: If you are coming from a very predictable schedule, this will be a difficult for you. The best people who thrive here, have developed a certain resilience that allows them to problem solve, be strong team members who help each other and work hard.

pros: Really dynamic, innovative workplace that allowed me to hone new skills and work with incredible colleagues
cons: It's winding down. :-( So sad to see it's Canadian operations dismantled because of the summer's media firestorm.

review_title: If you see challenges as opportunities, then you will succeed here.
pros:
- Great people
- You will get about 5 years of real-world experience with every year you work there
- You have opportunities to be an intrapreneur within the company
- Opportunity to travel to the countries we work in
- Do work that makes a real difference in the world
cons:
- Things will be HARD. It doesn't matter what role you are in there is always some kind of BS you need to deal with on a daily basis.
- Executives micro-manage ALL employees, there is no sense of ownership over any project you work on
- Have started to "sell their soul" to the corporate world, will take sponsorship from just about anyone who throws money at them - even if they don't align with the values of the organization.
- Are also starting to hire a lot of people whose values don't align with the organization, ruining the tight culture
- The charity aspect of the organization is starting to slowly disappear, focused more on consumer products

pros: A lot of opportunities to grow and gain new experiences
cons: Very little transparency in the organization

pros: working with students and teachers
cons: mental health of staff is not respected

review_title: Challenging, Interesting and Like No Other
pros: Working at the Free The Children has certainly not only opened doors to great opportunities, but it has also allowed me to grow into a stronger professional than I thought I would be in my 20's. Working on a wide variety of projects has helped to recognise areas that I want to strive further in, as well come to acknowledge certain areas of the non-profit sector that I don't share a heavy interest in. I especially enjoy the culture and atmosphere of which everyone works within. Collaborative and innovative, staff come together on a regular basis to discuss how we can improve and what type of campaigns we want to launch. I can confidently say that after working for a variety of companies, I now know that I thrive under this leadership and management style.
cons: Challenges when working at Free The Children would certainly include the pace and the hours. For many, these working styles are not appealing, however for someone with a lot of ambition and looking to be part of something larger, I enjoy it. Working in a high volume organization builds you out to have strong time management skills and when you love what you do for a living, you don't really mind going the extra mile on projects.

job_title: Human Resources Associate in Toronto, ON
pros: Great sense of community, working together to reach a common goal
cons: Low pay, awful management, exploiting young people fresh out of university for low pay and high demand work.

pros:
I've been at Free The Children for only a year. I have a corporate background. I was a culture shock for me that everyone was so kind and empathetic. While the hugging instead of handshakes is a little bit much, I can't believe the family spirit. The other week another department made us breakfast to celebrate our hard work. I've never heard of that before. We had a party to celebrate a successful We Day season and end of the school year. 
The opportunities I've had and challenges I've met have been among the best I've had in my six year career. I see many routes I can go.
My director is really kind and supported me through a recent illness. So was HR.
I am surprised by the negativity on here. The only people I can think of who would write such angry emails are people who didn't quite fit in with the culture or their hopes and  values didn't align. There is huge flexibility in work hours and location.
cons:
Very fast paced. Decisions are made very quickly. You have to work effectively and efficiently. 
Some long hours -- but can take lieu time to make up for weekend work.

review_title: Great place to learn but very demanding
pros: lost of opportunities & dynamic teams
cons: very uncoordinated, leadership is very concentrated at the top

pros:
- lots of autonomy, no one ever really told me what I needed to be working on and by when..very self -  driven which I liked but others may not  
- purpose-driven work
- good travel opportunities (Kenya, India, USA, UK etc.) 
- We Day is a great experience and a fun event to work 
- Often working on projects that are beyond your years, which presents a good opportunity to experience challenging work and pushes you to be better 
- People are "well-meaning"... people work there because they really do care about creating positive change so was good to meet like-minded people
cons:
- underpaid, under-appreciated, overworked (like...wayyyy over-worked) 
- lack of professional development. Your boss will be too busy to spend any time coaching you or they won't be good enough at their jobs to teach you anything worth learning 
- little benefits.... any money I did making I ended up spending on contacts, dental etc. 
- I worked on Thanksgiving two years in a row...no overtime pay..no "lieu" days to compensate 
- People worked extremely inefficiently..resulting in teams having to completely re-do everything .. more than once..

job_title: Executive Communications Specialist in Toronto, ON
pros: Great coworkers with learning abundant learning opportunities
cons: Low pay and long hours

pros: I'm a mid-career professional who came from another company and sector. WE values my contributions, encourages me to mentor younger staff, and is constantly innovating. I'm up for all of this -- plus I like that my contributions are for good, not just the bottom line.  I also adore the people I work with. No one better. I also work with the founders on a regular basis and I am full of admiration for their brilliance and commitment. They are also thankful for our efforts and share that thanks.
cons: The founders are workaholics, with endless vision, and they expect the same from everyone. That's tough some times. Because they are visionary and always pushing the envelope, it means there have to be a lot of operational hotshots around to put vision into action. So I find that challenging, but I enjoy the speed, energy and also belief that we can make things better.  I find that some of my colleagues who have come from corporate sector don't thrive in the 'start-up for social good' mentality and have trouble keeping pace. No knock against them, this just isn't their place.

review_title: Learned a lot, wasnt paid well
pros: Great learning experience for new graduates
cons: Salary was not comparable to industry standards

pros: Great Team, people and a place to grow
cons: Too much hierarchy and does not always feel transparent.

review_title: A ton of opportunity to learn, grow and develop in your career. Passion and hardwork required.
pros: I've been with the organization for a combined total of 7 years. Having left and come back, I've seen (and been part of) this place grow in it's impact and in it's focus on it's people. It's not perfect but the people are truly what makes this place feel like a family. If you're passionate, willing to take ownership and responsibility for your career and build some career capital, you'll do well here.
cons: It's challenging at times to work with people you tend to genuinely care about. There's a line that we cross sometimes between co-workers and friends. That's a good and a challenging thing. Because we're a fairly young organization (with our staff being primarily Millennial) we're constantly searching for new and innovative ways to do things. This can, at times, make us more reactionary than proactive.

pros:
-working here gave me the skills to prepare for my current job
-made a good network of professional contacts across many different areas
-people stay in touch and are connected to help each other with future job opportunities and business opportunities
-given a wide level of responsibility that truly prepares you for anything that comes your way afterwards
-travel the country and global experience that is of value to my current role
-you will go to your next role far better prepared and become serious competition for your new colleagues with your ability to problem solve, innovate and get stuff done quickly
-people you work with at FTC and the contacts you make here are setting themselves up to have serious influence in the future - current alumni have gone on to work in corporate sector, government, public sector and in C-level roles and beyond
cons:
-you will be challenged
-high growth work environment, fast moving- not for everyone if you are looking for structure and predictability
-high volume and stressful at times

pros: I whole heartedly disagree with the previous post. Perhaps one or two individuals who work here that may feel this way, but I can assure you that many employees spend years here building their skill sets and making undeniable impact. The organization gives people unbelievable opportunities to develop skills, travel and forge life long relationships. The organization gives its employees global reach, exposure and influence. The organization has really stepped up to support managers and teams. I've worked in environments that are stuffy, pretentious, where ten people have to look through one memo draft, where the whereabouts of people are tracked day and night through tools like slack. Environments where  co-workers track and report your every move- WE is not like that. We hire responsible adults and gives them ownership to do their work. I've been in environments where people sabotage your projects, steal you work and take credit from right under you and do not help you so you fail, I can assure you WE is not like that. People care! Management invest in you. The previous post undermines the hard work of me and my colleagues which is very unfortunate and sad. Extremely.
cons: This role involves patience and flexibility its not a typical 9-5 type of employment

review_title: Hoping it will change one day
pros: a cool story to tell your friends.  Parents off your back for  a few months if you need a job.   A way to fill a void on a resume.   Travel to neat places if you ever get the chance.   Brand recognition for those who only know the company from We Day or charity mentioned (although finding more and more that informed or sophisticated external folks don't respect the brand as much / at all)
cons:
cult of personality built around founders.
tough and unreasonable demands coupled with intimidating and demoralizing "training".  Ambiguity around strategy, operations and finances.  Pay is even more embarrassing once you have another job and realize how little you were paid relative to what you gave.   Countless questionable practices that most current or former employees can trade stories endlessly about

review_title: Great work experience and amazing people
pros: Really good experience, and you'll make great friends and connections. You'll be given a lot of responsibility (meaning you'll have a lot of work, too) but try to see that as a pro and get as much knowledge and experience out of this as possible. You don't NEED to burn yourself out or work 70 hour weeks - just stay organized and manage your time well. Flexible with vacation, lieu time and appointments. Most management is supportive and trustworthy. If you're positive, hard working and make an effort to know and learn from senior leaders you'll go far.
cons: Pay is very bad and doesn't reflect the hours and effort. Water cooler gossip is par for the course at any job, but when you consider that everyone here is very young and all friends personally, it's better not to get involved in that stuff. It's an expectation that you're available by phone an email 24/7 but just establish boundaries for yourself.

review_title: Not for intelligent, creative, independent spirits
pros: The pros of working at FTC are meeting a lot of young people, some of whom are intelligent and ambitious. For newcomers to Toronto, this allows you to built a community. It is fun to work events like We Day, and you may have the chance to travel on volunteer trips as facilitator (all expenses paid for).
cons: Professionally-speaking, FTC did not add very much to the independent, self-driven, creative part of my self. The culture pushed down from the people up top is aggressive, oppressive, and stifling to any demonstration of individuality. While there are brilliant and accomplished people generating this creative leadership, the job for everyone else is to execute to the best standard possible with no room for any meaningful ownership of one's work. This was particularly true in my department (Youth Programming),  where the majority of employees are essentially expected to be happy, amenable oompa-loompas. That is okay for some people, but can be very discouraging for others. I was certainly in the latter group, and I left very discontent with my job and management.

review_title: Unmatched opportunity for learning and growth.
pros: For those that have the energy, Free The Children offers unmatched opportunities for young people to learn and grow as professionals.  I have been on the team for 5 years beginning at entry level, and have gained experience and opportunities to take on responsibility at levels far beyond others my age.  In addition to these opportunities, the culture at Free The Children also makes this workplace special.  It's a pleasure to work alongside so many positive and ambitious individuals who really care about what they do.
cons: As the organization has face rapid growth over the last number of years, the workload is heavy across all teams.  While this can feel like a lot to take on, those that are successful within the organization see this as a learning opportunity, and all part of what it is to work with an international organization that is always looking for new and unique ways to expand the work that it's doing.

pros:
Working with FTC enabled me to:
- work with a collaborative and engaging team that are passionate about making positive change in the world
- Engage in a wide variety of different roles and responsibilities that allowed me to grow as a professional
- work outside of my comfort zone and push myself to strive for more
- think outside of the box 
-travel the world
- bring forward new ideas
- learn how to be a better manager and support my team in a larger way
- work in an organization that truly cared about making a positive change in the world
cons: Working with FTC you definitely have to be willing to put in some time and work hard...but where in life will you not find that...

pros: Some people get to work in the new office, which is nice. But most of us are in other buildings that are not even close to being to code.
cons: We are all squished in an old building that is falling apart. Adding paint doesn’t solve the problem here. Salary for a Coordinator is $32,000 and there is no negotiation. You would be better off working at the mall or doing an unpaid internship at a company that will pay you a living salary after the internship is over. The people in management positions are just the people who didn’t leave within their first year. No people management skills and no opportunity to learn and grow. All the positive reviews on here have been posted by the Marketing team. We were all told to post a positive review to boost the ratings... It’s still not working.

pros:
if you are self motivated you will thrive in this place. In my experience if I came across an issue I was given the autonomy to make/implement solutions.  Well thought out ideas, concepts and plans are very well received. Over 3 years of employment, I learned how to problem solve, develop solutions, present them effectively and gain buy in.  This is an example of one transferable skill I will take forward with me in my career.

If you aren't afraid to fail a few times and dust yourself off and try again...this is the place for you.  FTC is growing at a rapid pace and sometimes that means learning new things in uncharted territories. Mistakes happen and I was always encouraged to find another way around the problem. Coworkers from all departments were willing to pitch in and help, no matter how busy. It is an extremely collaborative and solution focused environment.

Sure I worked hard, but I learned more than I would in any other job. I was given responsibility that very senior level people in other organizations would be given at my age. I am grateful for the experience and professionalism I gained. My advice, dig in and invest in your career! 

The people...just amazing people. You will make life long friends here and bump into past FTC people all over Toronto/world.  You belong to a very special group of people whether you are past or present staff.
cons:
My advice to individuals who are interested in working here:
Opportunities are everywhere in the organization and management will advocate for you if you are positive, hard working and solution focused. People who are entitled, unmotivated and have poor attitudes have a hard time seeing them. If there isn't an opportunity for you...it's because you are entitled, unmotivated and have a poor attitude.  Things aren't handed out, you need to earn them. Don't expect to be promoted just because you have been there for a year. Prove you ability to lead by making impacts and being a team player. Trust me, this is recognized and doesn't go unnoticed. If you are unnoticed...see the section above about being entitled, unmotivated and having a poor attitude.

review_title: There are rules for the leaders, then rules for employees
pros: Any job gives you experience, no matter what it is.
cons: There are many fundamental problems with this organization but I will focus on one. Their salary structure is practically slave labor. For an organization which supposedly seeks justice, it's not fair to expect staff to work for paltry amounts. The founders have made a career out of their organization, but the don't expect any one else to make enough to do the same. It is abuse of young people to offer them hyped up jobs, but then assume they will just disappear after a few years and get a real job.   This is not the way to change the world. This is a human rights issue. But they don't care because there will always be eager young people willing to work for an disorganization which  seems cool. I have found a real NGO which actually respects that committed people with skills should be paid fairly.

pros: I would like to clarify for readers that the organization does indeed have pay band and job levels. Job levels range from coordinator to executives. Within these levels there are managers, specialists, associates, directors, director heads and so on.  Each level has a set of job responsibilities and the skills needed for the job. Each level is compensated within the job level. To be fair, the organization makes it very clear from the beginning that due to maintaining a low admin fee, salaries are not high however they more make than make up for that with their total rewards strategy which includes a positive culture, perks like wellness, birthdays off and lots of free coffee. We have excellent learning opportunities. Its not for everyone but those of us that love it stay!
cons: need to be able to juggle many balls in the air.

pros: Travel opportunities, talented staff
cons: Leadership does not care about their staff and the pay is unliveable. I had been with WE for years and it took months for me being out of it to realize the negative effects it had on my self esteem. A few of the heads feel pressure from the top down and everyone under them feels the pressure. A lot of the management is not experienced enough as people leaders to be in their role, and the “mission based” view is not an excuse for how staff are treated. While I am grateful for the time I had, and the development work done, working here is not sustainable for anyone.

review_title: Bad Leaders, Bad Experience, Just All Around Bad
pros: Made some life long friends at the organization
cons: I worked at Free The Children for over a year, which was is pretty uncommon at the organization. Many people leave after a few months. Leadership seems to be filled with people who were unpopular in high school and are taking out their aggression on poor 20-something idealists. Directors love to gossip about others behind their backs and create a overwhelmingly unwelcoming environment. Instructions are never clear and it is generally the lowest people on the totem pole who are blamed when something inevitably goes wrong. I saw and heard many things in my time there that made me question the ethics of this organization.

pros: Free The Children gives young people who don't have much experience a chance to work on big projects and carry big responsibilities. You get to grow your skills, get to work on large scale events and have big partner names to put on your resume.
cons: Management is not the best. The team is always criticized with no discussions on creating solutions, the departments are micromanaged and the workload is insane. There is hardly any down time and staff are always overworked with very little acknowledgement. The is no lieu time and over time pay is out of the question. The turnover rate and the number of unhappy staff is very high.

review_title: Lots of Pros and Cons, but definitely not what it seems
pros:
-Nice people and gain friendships, lots of like-minded folks
-lots of opportunity for personal & professional growth
-fun environment, sometimes spend afternoons in the park, outings, etc
cons:
-Most of the positive reviews are written by the HR team, it's painfully obvious with the messaging they're using, which bumps up ratings (hence my 1 star)
-The don't give you a break, if you're working 60-70+ hours a week you get no over time, no lieu time, definitely not up to employment standard's act... Sometimes they may let you come in at "11AM" on Monday after working a weekend, but honestly make it seem like they're doing you a favour
-So much hypocrisy (the morals and messages in the "me to we" book are NOT what they preach 
-Development work is not necessarily a good thing. Think about it & learn more before committing your life to this position for a few years

pros:
You create an unbelievable network
You work with the most amazing, driven people in the world
You are almost always given tasks you are unqualified therefore you learn a lot on the job
You get to travel the world while you give back
There is a lot of flexibility
cons:
You work very long hours
Management can be unrealistic with expectations
You don't actually get much creative control
There is a lack of process

pros: The people here are out of this world, they are so dedicated and care tremendously about making a difference. There are so many professionals who could work anywhere but to choose to work here. No matter what anyone says, the organization does change lives and brings something so needed in this world. There are people that complain here but still work here, I wonder why? If it is that terrible, why do people stay?   Also the new office is stunning. Great organizational culture and good people.
cons: This organization does ask a lot of it's staff but I know many people who rise to the challenge and excel. They grow their careers based on the experiences they have here.

review_title: Left disappointed and disallusioned - don't come here with high hopes!
pros:
My fellow managers and coordinators were incredibly talented, passionate and intelligent.  They were the reason I came to work everyday.  

You get your birthday off and the office closes during the holiday period for a week.  

They are trying to create a more positive employee experience with social events.

The work can be really great depending on your position.  

There are travel opportunities (though a lot of unpaid overtime work is involved in these).
cons:
The salary is low, even for a charity. It is actually below what is considered the cost of living for Toronto (which is ironic considering the goals of the charity). Most staff struggle to make ends meet. On top of that, staff are expected to work a great deal of unpaid overtime - late into evenings and especially on weekends. This overtime is disguised as part of the "culture" so that staff feel bullied into working it. If they do not work the unpaid overtime it is reflected in their annual reviews.  

While most staff can barely afford necessities, the majority of Directors live in free staff housing. (The organization says it is discounted accommodated and not free, however the rent equals in a year what most people pay in a month in Toronto - so for the sake of this review, we'll call that free). The staff housing was originally intended to make up for how low the salaries were. This is no longer the case, and most of the staff housing is used by Directors. These Directors have worked at the organization for a number of years and though they have been promoted beyond the super low salaries, they have continued to live in the staff housing. This means that those making the most at the organization are those taking advantage of the low rent, while those making the lower salaries must find a way to meet the crazy Toronto rental prices. There are a couple houses available for coordinators however they are not the private apartments that Directors live in - instead they student housing where you have to share rooms with your own colleagues.   

The vacation allowance is pitiful. On top of how demanding they are with weekends and evenings, they offer the minimum vacation required in Canada and no more. Half of the year is a blackout period too.  Yes, the office closes for a week during the holidays but this hardly makes up for the hours employees work in overtime. There is no time in lieu either for weekend work.  

The senior management has largely been promoted due to length of service rather than actual experience. As a result they have responsibilities that they cannot handle, and their skills have never been "checked" meaning they often do not have appropriate people managing / project management experience. Because they have been at the organization for so long however, staff are expected to just go with what they think is right and are not supposed to question decisions. It can be very frustrating for those who have had jobs and careers outside of the organization when the people you are working for have never.  
The biggest issue with this organization is what they consider their "culture". I was recently told by someone who had no idea what my employment history was that "if organizations truly live and breathe their culture, they don't need to hang their values on the wall of every room". This is the greatest way to sum up working for Free The Children. They hang their values on every room in every building, but hardly live them. They also disguise bullying, overtime, etc as "culture".  If you don't "volunteer" your personal time, you are not a "cultural fit".  Humility, gratitude and appreciation?  Let's start with the co-founder who everyone fears and avoids at all costs.  

A number of other reviews mentioned the forced trips on school buses to the "staff retreat". Yes, this does feel like a cult. Staff are forced to learn word for word the "key messaging" of the organization and then repeat these mantras in front of the co-founder who will go after you if you get a word wrong. You are sent up on the weekend and forced to stay overnight...with no overtime or time in lieu. You're usually lucky if the showers and toilets are working (that is not a joke).  

Staff are undervalued and continuously treated in a disposable way. Without disclosing too much, the employment awards are a joke and not a reflection of what development, training, etc opportunities are available.

I loved this organization when I joined it. I was hopeful and enthusiastic. My feelings only took about a month to change though and by the time I left not a single co-worker asked me why - instead they all told me they were jealous that I was getting out. What outsiders see is a facade. What is truly behind the walls is a negative environment where staff are given no reason to stay. The organization is unwilling to grow and understand that it is no longer the small grassroots charity it previously was.  It is filled with talented people who believe in the cause but have had other careers and thus have realistic expectations on what an employee should offer. With a few changes people would be willing to stay but instead those that speak out are considered negative.

pros: I spent 4 years with them and when I moved to my new role, people were shocked at what I was able to contribute to my new team.  My new colleagues were impressed with my ability to relate to our customers, public speak and get stuff done.  The team I currently manage is filled with people who are 10- 15 years older and I would have never gotten this role if I didn't have the experience I got at FTC.  I have people who are 45-50, coming to ask me how to use social media, how to build relationships and how to get around things when they are stuck. I learned at FTC how to be resourceful and get things done quickly.  I love my current job but really miss being able to step away for a coffee when I wanted, run errands, work from a coffee shop etc.  I miss the flexibilty big time.  I also loved wearing jeans everyday, business clothes cost more!  Working there helped me build my resume and people do take FTC experience seriously. I had to chose between 2 jobs, everyone knows that FTC staff are all stars!  I also miss working closely with vibrant co-founders, now I work with line managers who are cool but lack vision and excitement.
cons: The org is growing alot and I get how that can be tough, it is fast paced. If possible they should slow down.  I have kept in touch with friends there, I see that steps are being taken in the right direction.  Amidst the growth, they need to hire the right people who will have fun there like I did the 4 years I was there.

review_title: Valued my experience- was there almost 5 years
pros:
-travel ops, as someone said facilitation is a great side gig 
-awesome people - best kind of people
-strong org impact- empowers kids here and overseas- Adopt a Village is a solid model
-low admin rate- great donor accountability- no wastage like other charities
-good experience for those looking to understand business- few former staff I know now work out of places like CSI doing their own projects
-improved staff retreats- used to be out of town and on weekends, now I hear they are at Cineplex with guest speakers, popcorn and musical performances
-excellent network- found my current job through the network not just the friends I know but I left with great professional contacts -the org is good at helping you build these connections and they don't have to do that (ie through learn and leads, portfolio management etc)
-free snacks, food and coffee
-good parties and celebrations- xmas party was with partners and had a musical guest -they try their best given tight budgets
-instances where people have returned to the org after leaving
-flexible work environment
cons:
-I think a big issue is not having one office building. Right now there are so many buildings and I think that best practices don't get translated when departments operate in silos.  For instance there are so many departments with strong leadership but these best practices aren't always seen because people are in different buildings
-its interesting to see some negative reviews from current staff who are still working here, as an alumni i will always speak favourably about about my time with FTC because it gave me so much as a young professional 
-not an easy place to work but it builds excellence and character if you thrive

pros: Amazing co-workers who influence you to do better and keep you motivated and supported. A lot of young energy around the organization.
cons:
Low salary
Little meaningful recognition for the work that you do
Office space getting too crowded but the new campus opening next summer should help solve this issue

job_title: Manager of IT in Toronto, ON
pros:
The single greatest benefit of non-profit work is the satisfaction you feel while working. The ability to directly influence and help a weaker section of society is extremely rewarding. And Free The Children can give you this rewarding satisfaction.

Working with Free The Children will help you building on your leadership skills and it open your mind and gain a sense of perspective and start seeing the impact of small things. You realise what is more important

working culture is very friendly and everyone is eager to help each other.
cons: sometimes have to work for very long hours

review_title: Incredible launching pad for young professionals
pros:
FTC is a dynamic work environment that offers young professionals a significant amount of responsibility. While that can be challenging to navigate at times, the amount of personal and professional growth I've experienced myself and observed in my colleagues has been immeasurable. After seeing my experience, a friend with an MBA and 10 years in the corporate workplace recommends new MBA grads come work for a charity like this if they want to see the greatest growth in the shortest timeframe.

You work with truly exceptional people doing work that actually makes a difference. You can trust that people are really working hard to do the right thing and consistently improve. It's an intense place to work but I think I would be bored elsewhere!

Though the salaries may not be high by industry standards, when you consider the overall set of formal benefits (full compensation package) and the professional experience and network you develop while working here, it's well worth signing on. It's an amazing place to start or advance a career.
cons:
The organization is constantly evolving from its very small, grassroots origins into a much larger and more effective organization, and there are inevitably lots of learnings and bumps along the way. Open communication and a desire to be part of and contribute to the organization's evolution--the amazing stuff and the challenging stuff--is essential to succeed. If someone wants a highly structured workplace with lots of long-standing protocols and strict boundaries on work and personal (not better or worse--just different!), then I can see how they might become frustrated.

Prospective employees have to really listen when the HR team talks about the degree of commitment required to succeed in the organization, and to weigh whether it's the right fit for them, personally. This organization won't be the right fit for everyone, and that's okay! For the people who are looking for this kind of workplace, it can be transformational.

review_title: you are in for crazy ride like nowhere else!
job_title: Youth Programming Coordinator in Vancouver, BC
pros: My past 3 years here have been some of my most amazing 'discovery' years ever! i have traveled to distant lands and met some truly wonderful people
cons: I would love to see the co-founders more and engage with them on strategic directions

review_title: You will never find such great people or experiences... but it can play a toll on you.
pros:
-You meet some of the best people in the world at this organization. There are many genuine, kindhearted, accepting peers and it is easy to make friends and feel comfortable.
-You get amazing experiences whether it be working directly with the youth involved in FTC programming, working with educators, learning about the development practices, facilitating overseas to see the communities firsthand, etc.. these are experiences you likely will not find anywhere else.
-Organization is really well known in Canada, making it a great stepping stone for Canadians. In the US, they are just starting to gain traction, so it doesn't get you as far in a career as it would in Canada.
-There's opportunities to join other teams and try new roles
-Really great culture amongst team members and peers
cons:
-There is room for growth, but you need to have the right people on your side and be ready to be molded into their idea of a leader.
-In my experience (and other friends who have left as well), there is a lot of hypocrisy when it comes to work style and work/life balance. For instance, you are told to always ask questions, but when you seek support you are often made to feel like you should have tried it on your own. As for work/life balance, there barely is any. You aren't "expected" to be on your email or reachable all the time, but there's a feeling in the air when you come in and didn't check your email last night and your manager had sent something.. you know you're supposed to always check it, but they just can't say that. 
-On the contrary, if you do move up, be prepared to check your email 24/7. And respond.
-The pay for coordinators is ridiculous, very hard to live off of... However, you make up for it in experience (I do really believe that)
-HR/Accounting still don't understand the American system when it comes to things like taxes, budgets, etc. Going international means you need to be an expert of each country's laws and practices, not just Canada's.
-Different jobs have different demands and that isn't always recognized/worked around. For example, speakers and facilitators are often on the road before the sun comes up, but rarely given the opportunity to leave early or lieu time off.

I've seen a few people post things about exit interviews and how you should voice these opinions there... and yes you should, if you get one. Personally, when I left, I expressed my reasons and grievances with my AD and Director, and surprisingly enough, they never scheduled me an exit interview with HR. If you don't agree with how the organization is run or other related items (such as partnerships with horrific companies), be prepared to keep your mouth shut or have it follow you around for your career.

review_title: Do yourself a favour , don’t work here
pros:
Birthdays off.  

Christmas shutdown.  Managers tell staff that Christmas shutdown is a bonus but it really isn’t 
when you work unpaid stat holidays , evening  and weekends year round. Not to mention the 60+hours a week staff have to work during We Day. Ultimate slave labour. They take advantage of young workers and interns looking for experience. 

After having worked here I’ve been able to stop friends and family who had been interested in applying.
cons:
Compensation:  
Almost poverty line. Coordinators make $27,000 annually and work from 9 - 6. They are then expected to work in the evenings and weekends without pay. You could probably make more working at Tim Horton’s – at least they pay time and half/overtime. Extremely difficult to live off such a low wage can’t even subsidize your income with a second job because they have you by the neck. 

Management: 
Managers/ Directors are so young and have these over inflated titles (most which don’t even make sense). 90% of them don’t have any related experience or any other work experiences except within the walls of Free The Children/ Me to We. If you’re looking to learn and be mentored this doesn’t happen here.  They regurgitate the same nonsense over and over again. It’s actually sad that most of them have made themselves uncompetitive and probably wouldn’t cut it in the real world. 

Bully mentality from the top down. Managers and Directors are quick to throw their staff under the bus when things go wrong. It’s not uncommon to receive hurtful and harassing emails.  Office environment itself is very gossipy and a lot like high school. Lack of professionalism is a big problem.

Retention: 
This place is revolving door. At least half the people you onboard with leave or are fired within a few shorts months. The on boarding program is also a big waste of time. It’s a full week of some guy drilling you with information about the organization, departments & core values. 

We Day: 
Cool if you’re on the outside looking in. Staff are working 60+ plus hours a week for months leading up to the day in addition to keeping up with their daily jobs. The 3 event days are an absolute nightmare! Unless you’re a brown noser or a friend of We Day Directors chances are you’ll get a crappy physically intense job and will want to die a million deaths. 
We day is usually most enjoyed by those selected to wrangle D List celebrities like Shawn Desmond and have their pictures taken with them. 

Culture:  
Very fake culture. You have to know the core values and get tested on them either on the spot or during bogus “staff retreats” (which are actually a 2 day brainwashing sessions- typically booked on staffs personal time).  Rules that apply to coordinators don’t apply to Managers  & Directors.

pros: -good staff support physiotherapist for all staff, he travels with the team while on the road, lots of snacks and meals, which really helps, the people here are amazing
cons: Not a 9-5, you will work hard but you will grow professionally

pros: None that I can think of
cons: The most recent Canadaland article outlining the poor working conditions is spot on. Even though some of the grievances outlined were outdated, they are still relevant. There is an overarching assumption that you should be on a 24 hour work cycle, pressured into working overtime with no lieu hours provided, being made to feel guilty for having another job, having HR tell you to suck it up when you bring up being paid less then minimum wage for the amount of responsibility you have, being put on the spot in team meetings to be made to feel like you aren't as committed as other people, and put into inappropriate and uncomfortable situations like sharing a hotel room with your Director.

review_title: Amazing people to work with, and lots of career opportunities
pros: Free The Children is a challenging and fun workplace especially for young people. You are working with amazing group of people that become your long-time closest friends. People here always help each other to grow. There are lots of career opportunities in the organization. With the mentorship from managers and directors, many staff here including me have developed considerable skill base, explored different career paths. And we continue to grow with the organization.
cons: With the rapid growth in the past few years, workload is increasing across all teams. Strategic planning is always the priority in the organization.

pros:
Great environment in terms of learning new and valuable skills
Great co-workers
Pretty neat area of the city
cons:
Incredibly intense in terms of pursuing prospects and supporting partners. Not necessarily a bad thing, sincere commitment is good, but they don't staff enough coordinators and interns to make it sustainable (i.e. staff end up working overtime quite a bit). 

Pay is pretty low relative to the amount of work put in.

review_title: Good for young people starting off in the non-profit world, but long hours.
pros: If you're young and willing to work hard in an international non-profit, FTC will give you plenty of opportunities to develop your knowledge of the field and have you tackle important responsibilities without a Master's and/or 5+ years of experience, which is what is usually required by other NGOs. If you love working with youth, it's definitely the place to be -- our work is centered around youth and youth-driven. The community development model used by FTC to support communities all around the world is a holistic one that WORKS, and it's great to see the tangible results after helping to do school-building work when visiting these areas. We work hard, but play hard, too.
cons: Our staff seems to be stretched to their capacity, with everyone doing so much that we can't seem to keep with our programs sometimes. Feedback offered by on-the-ground employees (individuals who work with the youth who support our programs) seems to go in one ear, out the other, of management people. We're so eager to expand on what we do, but without the proper resources and time allocated to get really good at what we're already doing. There needs to be more recognition of what has been done well, properly reward staff for their achievements and hard work, and take into account what the "lower-level" team members have to say, because they know what's going on in the day-to-day details. Work seems to consume our lives during the busy times, as the amount of work that needs to be done comes in "waves" -- sometimes it's really slow, sometimes it's hectic and filled with non-stop work. There needs to be a better balance.

review_title: Career with ability to create change
pros:
I had the opportunity to begin working at FTC straight out of school. Now nearly 6 years later I have made a career for myself that has been self-satisfying and given me opportunities unlike anything I could have imagined. 

I have read the reviews here and there are negative reviews about staff being young. It's actually quite a pleasure to work with enthusiastic young people who make my day to day work fun. There are a mix of ages represented at the organization and I feel proud to work for an organization that is able to provide employment in an exciting field of work for some many young graduates as well as many seasoned professionals. FTC actually has the best of the best people working here when it comes to passion and dedication. 

Having started as a young graduate to now being a more senior staff member, I can confidently say how the organization has evolved and grown not just in the programs we implement but also in the way staff are cared for and listened to. 

Everyone works hard but I can honestly say I have an excellent work-life balance. You can make a career for yourself at FTC and because at a young age, we are given great responsibilities, we are able to create change. We can create new processes and systems, we can influence project development and have fun while doing it next to some of the greatest people I know. 

Additional benefits of working at FTC:
- travel
- interactions with FTC/We Day celebrity ambassadors
- good vacation days and time off (they are also so flexible and accommodating with doctors appointments, etc)
- lifelong friends
- growth opportunities (laterally and upwards)
- learning opportunities. I want to explain this one further. I came to FTC with a passion for international development and that was my educational background. I'm lucky enough to have a job/career in this specific field doing what I'm passionate about. What I didn't expect to learn about but have, is the business side of not for profit work. I've learned business skills, communications, marketing, fundraising...all skills that will equip me to grow my own professional skill set. 

At the end of the day, you can work here and know you are a part of something that is bigger than yourself. Working at FTC you are part of an honest to god movement that is creating change both here in Canada and internationally.
cons: This isn't a con in my opinion but I feel I should it should be addressed because of comments I've seen on here. When you choose to work in a not-for-profit organization, understand that you are making a lifestyle choice and that's one I've happily made. As a salaried employee, I don't know any non-profits that pay overtime. Just like other companies and organizations, jobs need to get done and if that requires some extra time, then it requires extra time. FTC is flexible with its lieu days and offers other great benefits and opportunities. I am making a career out of my experience here at FTC and am so proud of the movement I know I am a part of.

pros: If you work yourself stupid you might get to meet a famous person or go on a trip...where you'll be worked stupid
cons:
So much.
There are a lot of horrible things about this organisation (belligerent co-founder, bullying, terrible compensation, ridiculous benefits, lies, exploitation...) but worst of all are the directors. These people are among the most terrible leader's I've ever had the misfortune of working with. The worst part is, they all think they're good at what they do.

job_title: IT Support Specialist in Toronto, ON
pros: Great place to work. Good benefits and they really work to promote talented people of all diverse backgrounds. Super important, particularly in today's world. For those in nonprofit sector, highlight recommend you take some time to work here at some point in your career or look at what they are doing especially around social enterprise which is the next trend in the sector. It is a rising trend which we need to see more of.
cons: Lots of work in the fall season.

review_title: Free the Free the Children Staff
pros: They hire some incredible people, but many leave feeling defeated and burnt out after only a few months of working there.
cons:
The people in management positions are not good leaders. The organization knows this is a problem and instead of actually trying to fix it, they offer managers lessons from the Co-Founder, who makes employees cry on a regular basis. 

The retention rate is the worst I've ever seen. Many employees don't last a year in their position, and to fill in gaps they overload the people who are still there until they're burnt out and also leave. 

Whenever someone questions why something is done, they are told by management that they are "not a team player", or are ""being negative". They will also try to guilt trip employees and not address the problem. 

They keep inventing new useless positions and hiring new people while not paying any attention to what the people who currently work there can and want to do. We are constantly being told that budgets are tight, so where is this money coming from?

Money is being mismanaged at every turn. I cringe to think about how many hundreds of thousands of dollars are being wasted each year on travel changes, not to mention sending the organization's stakeholders (who are usually millionaires) dozens of gifts each year. 

You will be paid very little for an obscene amount of work. Overtime is expected in most positions (with no compensation), and lieu days are rarely given. 

After being hired you will have to participate in "onboarding", a week long training program. You won't actually learn anything, but you will feel like you've been inducted into a cult. They will tell you how lucky you are to work there (stating some bogus "it's harder to get accepted into Harvard than to get hired at FTC" fact). This will be your first sign that the organization is run by egotistical crazy people and you should leave ASAP. 

There are some very shady HR practices going on. I've heard from numerous people that they offered a certain salary at the beginning of the hiring process, and by the end, they give them a significantly lower number. When they're asked about it, HR usually says someone made a mistake, or that the first number is at the high end of the range.

HR needs to stop posting fake reviews to drive the overall rating number up. I've talked to countless employees in multiple departments about what it's like to work there, and not one would ever give it a 5/5.

pros: The organization heavily in manager training into support of employees. This is a learning organization, always innovation and improving the employee experiences. As a young manager, I have been able to participate in a number of trainings that are equipping me to support my staff. The executives at WE spend considerable efforts working on improving experience while ensuring strong performance. Amazing training and learning plus many opportunities to travel and be a part of a global organization.
cons: not an average workplace- need to be self directed and passionate

review_title: All Hail the Kielburgers, but where does the money go?
pros:
Exceptional people previously, but they are now all replaced by unpaid volunteers
The organization actually is an innovator for a new-type of organization: a corporatist NGO
cons: Culture promotes Kielburger supremacy (antithetical to values of equality), organization makes up data on impacts, is led by dodgy corporate partnerships, sees youth as a product, sues critics

review_title: Micromanaged, overworked and ruled by fear
pros:
• Great colleagues/relationships 
• Good office location and space
• Looks great on the resume
cons:
• Work late constantly, weekends and holidays with no compensation
• Pay is pitiful
• Employees have low morale due to complete lack of ownership and a voice
• Workload is heavy and thankless because no one feels like they have any power over the product of their efforts

pros:
- love what the organization stands for 
- some employees really care about the work we do and the people we help
- relaxed working environment
cons:
- managers are not training properly and promoted because of time at the company not skill
- HR situations are handled poorly and unprofessionally
- "lifers" have a hard time adapting to a growing organization and still do things the way they were done 10 years ago

review_title: AVOID WORKING HERE AT ALL COSTS.
pros:
- Great immediate team members who are extremely intelligent and supportive.  The organization takes this enthusiasm and squashes it.
- Annual international travel opportunities
cons:
If only there was a negative star rating option.  Free The Children is clearly coercing individuals to write positive reviews to save their measly rating here giving a false representation of the company.

-Senior leadership treats employees with blatant disrespect and lack of trust.  Ideas are squashed almost immediately.  Employees (even at the director level) have a clear lack of autonomy to make decisions to propel work forward.  

-Zero room for professional growth and development

-Zero coaching for management

-Expectation of employees to carry extra weight and take on additional work as it builds up, even if that work is not within your job description, without compensation augmentation or title change.

-Organization is unwilling to invest in staff with more than 1-2 years experience resulting in leadership who have never worked anywhere other than Free The Children and have no other experience to contribute.  Promotions are given to those who stick around, not to those who merit it.  

-Goals and priorities for departments are consistently unclear which leads to fast burn-out and a mis-allocation of both employee time and company resources.

-Inconsistent performance reviews (as a manager working with the company for 3+ years, I haven't had a performance evaluation for over 1.5 years).

-One of the core values is "honoring every stakeholder"  ... what the company means by this is "honoring every stakeholder who donates large sums of money."  Staff are arguably the most important stakeholders and "beers and cheers" is not enough to honor and celebrate their work.  How about instead of paying for alcohol or food, you increase salaries to at least meet the minimum cost of living and then we can buy our own beers and a decent meal?

-Senior leadership has yet to prove that they are impeccable with their word.  There is no follow-through on promises made.  No consistent delivery on identified timelines.  

-No structure to meetings which generally is a giant waste of everyone's  time.

-Senior leadership expects employees to diligently log communication and notes in Salesforce, but then they don't do it themselves.

-I spend most of my time fighting to perform my basic role & responsibilities because of all of the last minute and irrelevant "urgent" (but not important) work requests that fall onto my plate from other teams within the organization.

-Organization is very short-sighted.

-Expectation for individuals to front company costs (transportation to/from meetings, etc.), and then reimbursements are hardly ever paid on time.  Sometimes large sums can take up to 3+ months, and you have to fight every step of the way to ensure you're getting paid for what you're due. 

-Terrible internal communication systems.  Email heavy.  Lack of knowledge around technology and info storage systems. 

-Organization often makes external promises it can't keep therefore forcing employees to be the bearers of bad news to external stakeholders.  

The list could go on and on, but this would then turn into a book.  After a significant amount of time with the company, I'm leaving feeling burnt out, used up, unacknowledged for the work I have been able to produce, and on terrible terms.  I cannot wait to move on to bigger and better things.  If you have any kind of professional goals, I highly recommend you DO NOT WORK HERE.

review_title: So much potential, but such a horrible place to work
pros:
• Incredible, passionate people – it is hard to find someone you won’t get along
with as a person here
• Holiday office shut down
• Free the Children really is doing the best job to help end the cycle of poverty and exploitation both locally and globally
• Laid back atmosphere, not a strict dress code.
cons:
• Taking advantage of passion
As I mentioned in my pros, I truly believe that FTC is doing the best job of
any other charity. As a result, it attracts the upper crust of amazing
individuals who are filled with energy and passion and love.  I have undergone,
and watched many others undergo a transformation from excitement, endless
energy and passion to disillusionment, sadness and angry bitterness after they
see, and experience FTC taking advantage of, and exploiting that passion to a
degree that is just sickening.  And truly heartbreaking.
• Retention
Retention is not a thing at FTC.  They view everyone as easily replaceable.  Their employees are not treated as assets and they are certainly not viewed as assets. They are viewed as a means to an end, or, a cog in a machine and they will watch, shrugging their shoulders as amazing individual after amazing individual smartens up and walks away. And then they will hire and train a new individual who is hopefully also amazing and the cycle will repeat. It is
not a good feeling to be a cog and it adds more to everyone’s plate to have to
constantly train new people and do their own jobs without the knowledgeable,
capable person that they watched walk away. It is staggering that no one has
realized how unsustainable this is. Or, more realistically, it is staggering
that people have recognized how unsustainable this is and have continued to let
it happen.
• Promotions
Because FTC is such a challenging place to work there is a ridiculous turnover rate.  The amount of people I saw come and go is actually laughable and should be enough to get the
attention of the leaders of this organization and instigate some sort of
change. With that being said, the people that do stay, get promoted.  That is the sole qualification FTC needs to see. It is important to say that there are a lot of incredibly talented, smart, creative people in positions of leadership at FTC but for the most part, the
people who are promoted into upper management roles are promoted because they have put their time in.  Not because they have any of the qualifications needed.  Not because they are even close to capable of the roles they are put into.  Certainly not because they have the ability to manage human beings.  But because they know what they are getting into and
continue to want to move up and this misguided sense of ‘loyalty’ is valued
beyond all else there.  I have seen gross displays of incompetence, rudeness,
and unprofessionalism that go unaddressed and are seemingly, rewarded, because
I’ve also seen the same people be promoted over others who are more competent, but haven’t been there long enough, or spent too much time in a coordinator role and consequently are not regarded with enough respect to move up.
I have also seen people that are smart, passionate and capable be
pigeonholed into jobs that they have hated.  Instead of recognizing the talent
they are so lucky to have, and cultivating these people into the roles they
belong in and will excel in, they trap them there under the pretense of needing
to “get the job done (period)”.  There limited examples of people
who have been lucky enough, to have had the right director at the right time to
be recognized and developed and promoted into their dream roles and the
contributions they are making to the organization are nothing short of
miraculous.  But this isn’t the norm.  It is 100% the exception to the rule and
just makes the rest of us question why we weren't been discovered for the
untapped potential we feel we have to offer as well.  I should mention that
this isn’t necessarily anybodies ‘fault’ because almost every single person in
this organization is too bogged down with too much work to have time to even
think about recognizing talent and cultivating potential.  People are simply
trying to get through each task and directors need each cog to function in the
way they’re supposed to in order for that to happen.
• Pay
There’s no need to say much about the pay.  It’s horrible.  People are
financially sinking in order to continue doing their work there.  I accumulated
more debt in interest on my student load than I was able to pay off.  So I ended
up in a worse financial situation leaving FTC than I was in starting out. Directors expect people to drop their entire
lives for this job and do not think for one second that they aren’t properly
recompensing them for that.  Another review mentioned that the hours and pay
are similar to other charitable organizations.  I have worked in several.  That
is a not true.
• Overtime
It is not unusual for FTC teams to be required to work over weekends and holidays.  This overtime is not reflected with higher pay, or lieu time off.
• PS.
One other review actually says the situation is not as bad at the negative reviews make it out
to be.  None of these reviews will prepare you for how terrible it is to work at FTC.  It is much
worse than could possibly be conveyed in any 3-4 paragraph review.

pros: If you are a young person applying you will meet lots of other young people that you will have fun with.
cons:
There really is an abundance of cons. First and foremost – the leadership. The fact that a director would have the nerve to come on here and write about “disgruntled millennials” honestly does not surprise me in the least. By doing that they have essentially vindicated what every bad review has said about the leadership in this organization – they are not willing to listen to any sort of criticism, if you disagree with something you are an over-entitled young person who is quite simply “not a culture fit”.
Reading through the reviews, I can’t help but notice the discrepancies between the HR responses to the negative reviews and the “positive” reviews that current directors are coming on here to write. HR states that the compensation is “on par with similar positions in other organizations” and that the days off that they give goes above and beyond the standard vacation allotment. Then the directors claim that being overworked and underpaid is what non-profit work is all about. So which is it exactly? Are we being paid according to industry standard or are we being underpaid? I’ll go with the latter. Since leaving FTC, I have moved on to another non-profit organization, where everyone works an 8 hour day (not necessarily 9-5) and if they do work above that they are fairly compensated, as per the law. Don’t let FTC manipulate you – this is not what non-profit work is like. The pay here is awful and so is the vacation time, considering that the majority of the year is considered a “blackout period” and you are not allowed to take vacation.
Like many others have stated, the majority of people who are in leadership roles in this organization shouldn’t be and I believe that they wouldn’t be in any other organization. You should not be a director simply because you have worked at FTC for 4 years. People management skills need to be developed – the amount of snarky banter that goes around this organization really makes you feel like you are back in high-school.

review_title: Don't believe the hype - stay away
pros:
-great, talented colleagues (at coordinator and management levels)
-birthday off
cons:
I find it very telling that so many "positive" reviews blame high the high turnover rates and negative reviews on those who have had those experiences and are leaving the organization.  They are confirming what so many reviews are saying, this organization refuses to look inward and understand the huge issues that are causing people to leave (and with such negative feelings).  In what world does an organization blame those who are leaving rather than try to understand why people are leaving?  And a note on those positive reviews, it is well known in the organization that HR requested staff to leave positive reviews to balance the feedback out - again refusing to acknowledge the major failures of this organization when it comes to its staff.  
I would also like to comment on the reviews that state those leaving refuse to work hard and don't have an understanding of the charity sector.  I had a successful career before and after FTC, including working for two other reputable charities.  Since leaving FTC I am in a role far more demanding and I work a lot harder than I ever had to at FTC, and am more than happy to do so because I am respected and treated well.  The idea that I and others left because we don't want to work hard is ridiculous.  I can also state that the pay, lieu time and overtime expectations at FTC are far below the industry standards so do not claim that this is standard for charities.  As a coordinator at another respected charity I made far more than I ever did as a manager at FTC.  This organization takes advantage of its employees to maintain a lower administrative rate.  If you don't want to pay overtime (for the forced overtime that you require of your staff), why do you also refuse to give lieu time?  Lieu time doesn't affect your admin rates and your staff will not be resentful for the manipulation and advantage that you take of them.  
What all other negative reviews have said are true, this organization forces overtime on staff and if you do not do it you are told you are not a "cultural fit" and your job is threatened. They use their "values and culture" (I use both terms incredibly loosely) to manipulate and bully staff.  Those in leadership roles have no business having the responsibilities that they do and have no real-world experience to lean on.  They lack crucial skill-sets, including people management skills, and as a result treat their direct reports horribly.  Because of the high turnover rate, employees get promoted far too quickly into senior roles without experience or leadership skills, further alienating staff and contributing to the ever increasing turnover rate. When employees complain or highlight the bullying and treatment from leaders, rather than support they are told to stay quiet and deal with it.  
FTC can blame going through "change" all that it wants (an excuse they've been using for years) but all organizations, big and small, go through change, including where I currently work.
