It is not the people leaving that are change-adverse, it is those who have been at the organization for more than 2 years who are change-adverse.  They refuse to acknowledge that their practices need to change and any new employee that comes on board with new ideas or dares to point out old practices that no longer work are declared negative and any enthusiasm that they had is stomped out of them.  I have never met a more miserable group of employees in my entire career, all so desperate to escape.
This organization refuses to acknowledge some serious problems within its walls (metaphorical and literal - people should not have to work in windowless garages with no heating and mice) and until they do I would not recommend that anyone work for FTC.  This place was by far the most negative employee experience that I ever had.  And again, this was not my first "real" job and it was not my last - so to those blaming these reviews on people who are work-adverse or don't know what a "real job" is - stop blaming those trying to address real issues and start looking inward.

pros: No pros. Horrendous management, corrupt organization, culture of lies and overworking employees.
cons:
Too many to list. Main one: my experience at FTC has continued to haunt me!

When I go to new job interviews with other, serious NGOs and organizations, the FIRST question they ask is some version of: "why did you work at FTC? We were skeptical of even giving you this interview because of this. Please explain". 

Once you leave the FTC bubble you realize that NOBODY (other than Telus, RBC, General Mills, and FTC sponsors), respects the organization. 

Do your resume a favour: don´t put Free The Children on it.

review_title: Misleading job descriptions, poor management, and bullying
pros: Despite all the problems, Free The Children manages to hire incredibly talented people who are a pleasure to work with. You will make friends and want to keep them even after you leave.
cons:
I was employed in the executive office with Free The Children for nearly 3 months of which I gained no professional experience, was given no opportunities to succeed, and - like many others who have come and gone - was bullied into adapting to the Free The Children culture. 

First, the job descriptions - at least for the executive team - are very misleading, and in some cases, down right lie about what the position entails. 

The job descriptions for the coordinators on the exec team suggest there are many opportunities outside of ghostwriting, this in most cases is not true. As such, any correspondence coordinator position on the exec team is actually an administrative assistant position. Even the manager position on the exec team is an admin position - executive assistant position at most. I truly believe that if the job descriptions were adjusted FTC would have more success at keeping their employees.

I gained no valuable professional experience as I was always doing the same monotonous work. There was absolutely no room to grow and this is immediately apparent after only a couple of weeks. Not to mention, the directors and associate directors - who lack little working experience outside of FTC - have poor management skills and prefer to "throw their coordinators under a bus" before assuming any responsibilities. Yes, the average age at FTC is 24; and yes, it shows. 

As other reviewers have mentioned, one of the biggest problems at Free The Children is how they forcibly impose their culture on their employees. New employees need to be indoctrinated where they spend a whole week "learning" about the values and culture of FTC. Not to mention you are expected to share personal details about your life with strangers you work with. What I found most interesting was how they expect their employees to sacrifice their life, schedules, and extra-curricular activities to their culture. So for example, if you want a balanced lifestyle and you don't want to live and breathe work, then FTC is not for you. FTC does not understand in any shape or form that their employees want to have lives outside of their work. It's quite sad actually how they will abuse and exploit their employees to no end, forcing them to work 60 hours a week without lieu time or overtime. Let's not forget that the annual salaries are sometimes lower than minimum wage; there is absolutely no compensation for dedicated, hard labour at Free The Children. I had one day that I was extremely ill and had to stay home and I was continuously harassed with phone calls and expected to work from home. I feel that FTC exploits their employees, forcing them to believe that they are working for a good cause, when in fact they are being overworked. 

Unfortunately, the cofounders have absolutely no interest in investing time in understanding why their executive team has a revolving door of people coming in and out of their office. They also have impossible expectations for their employees. I would like to note that this isn't entirely their fault, they are surrounded by "yes" people and have come to believe that anything can be done when they ask for it, even if it is unreasonable. I have seen the lack of professionalism that the cofounders have displayed on many occasions, such as sharing confidential information with colleagues without following professional procedures. They seem to not understand that a protocol for such conversations should be in place.

Everyone who has left Free The Children is given the chance to share their advice with their director and HR in an exit interview; unfortunately,  little effort is made to take these conversations seriously. I urge the cofounders, directors, associate directors, and human resources to take exit interviews seriously. Just because something has always been done a certain way, doesn't mean they can't be changed for the better. This is interesting advice to give an organization that advocates for active social change...

Career Opportunities: even a month at FTC will help you put up with anything that is ever thrown your way. However, if you are an applicant in the interview process at FTC, cancel your interview and hang tight for something better. If you are applying for a position on the exec team, avoid it all costs. That department is notorious for losing employees very quickly.

Compensation & Benefits: below minimum wage. A junior coordinator will get $25,000. No lieu time. No over time. No sick days (because you are expected to work from home on those days).

I also want to add that in my time at FTC it was mentioned that in response to the negative reviews on Glassdoor, human resources would try to add positive reviews to showcase what is "good" about working at FTC. Just goes to show the lack of credibility FTC maintains.

review_title: Full context for those mentioned exit-interviews
pros: You meet some amazing people who will be life-long friends if you are lucky enough to be put on the same team as them.
cons:
I would just like to comment on this point brought up by another reviewer below: 

"...those who don’t feel the need to vent behind an anonymous online forum. I hope these staff have shared their feedback in exit interviews, our leadership team is working to ensure an open and safe environment. It’s important that anyone reading considers the full context."

Have you ever thought that while employees are given the chance to air out their grievances during an exit interview, they are also doing so in the presence of future references?!?! Most exit interviews are conducted with 1) the HR director and 2) your immediate manager/director. Of course, you want to be honest with your feedback, but you wouldn't feel like jeopardizing a future reference on feedback (that likely won't be followed up on anyway). You simply aren't comfortable enough in that professional situation to do so, no matter how "safe a space" it might be. A forum like this one, where people can leave their honest thoughts ANONYMOUSLY (and why does everyone assume that if you're  anonymous and "negative" you are instantly a disgruntled troll?) about a place of work where they've dedicated energy and time, is incredibly valuable--ESPECIALLY when an exit interview is being conducted by potentially important characters in your job-hunt. Nobody wants to burn any bridges, that would just be foolish. 

Please  remember that if it's important to consider the full context of reviews, you must consider every angle.

review_title: Unreasonable expectations for insanely low salaries
pros:
- There are brilliant people who work here. It amazes me how hard working and intelligent some of the FTC/M2W staff truly are.
- Level of responsibility contrasted to level of experience here is unparalleled. Whether you're entry level or upper management you get a lot of responsibility for the years work experience you have under your belt coming in. This is a pro for experience, but a massive con too since there's zero training on how to properly manage/lead and do your job.
cons:
- Absolutely no leadership. Upper management is terrible and strong-arms their employees all the time. It is absolutely ludicrous the way FTC treats their employees. Insane amount of overtime work with no benefits at all. You're expected to work incredibly long days and have no outside life. Prepare to take your work home with you most nights. You're sometimes working 12 hour days and it's expected that you'll do it without hesitation. Say goodbye to any form of social or extracurricular life you have outside of work because your world will need to solely revolve around FTC.
- Terrible salary! Starting salary of $27,000 is just outrageous.
- There's a culture of not being able to voice any disagreement with what goes on. What upper management says, goes. No room for discussion.
- Turnover rate is very, very high. People honestly do think it's a shock when someone sticks around for more than 2 years. It's uncommon for a reason.

review_title: Energetic and entrepreneurial charity for social change!
pros: Culture is amazing - not for someone who doesn't care about working in a 'family' type of atmosphere!  Fast moving and entrepreneurial.  If you have a good idea - at any level - people will listen to you and, if possible, allow you to make it happen as long as you have a solid plan.  Lots of staff recognition like awards at staff meetings, official letters from founders to add to your portfolio when you've done outstanding work, birthday off, December holidays off and if you have  doc appointment or just need a morning off to get something done, you don't have to go through official channels most of the time.  They are a charity so can't give extra bonuses, gifts etc but they do what they can. A young workplace so everyone is energetic and always learning.  Coordinators and managers can be promoted very quickly if they are ambitious and passionate.
cons: It is a charity, so to be accountable to donors, it needs to keep admin costs to a minimum.  This means that the extra's like bonuses, gifts etc can't be given (when other charities do, it is front page news.)   I'm sure they would love to recognize their hard working staff this way, they just can't.  Long hours at some points but also when work is slow and you're done your daily work, you can usually leave a bit early.   If you need constant validation no matter what level of work you produce, it might not be the right place for you - this is an incredibly strong team!

pros: Will be given lots of learning opportunities and very cool projects to work on! You will learn quickly and make a positive impact in the world.
cons: Very fast-paced environment. It is competitive to work here and the energy levels and commitment to doing big things sometimes means long days and it's easy to burn out.

pros: The organization is evolving and changing for the better. In the many years I have been there, there have been many improvements to the employee experience- from improved time off, lieu days and Christmas off. Great benefits and colleagues. There is strong investment in people managers whereby managers continually add to their toolkits managing diverse and passionate employee base.
cons: There are normal growing pains which management is hard at work addressing

review_title: I Wish I Still Worked At WE Charity

cons: Longer hours but the impact made it worth it for me.

pros: Great colleagues. Team driven. Immense support from colleagues.

pros: The organization provides ample travel opportunities and the staff trip to Kenya was unreal. It was one the most challenging experiences I have ever had. I was also able to travel to Ecuador. I loved that my work was directly changing the lives of people and we influenced change. This is definitely the way to do it.

pros: The other people are the only pro to working at WE - they’re there to make a difference, but the organization is so poorly run that not much gets done despite the best efforts of everyone working below the “director” position.
